data.source: 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey (FHCS) administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management
data.wave_or_subset: 2006 FHCS; sample representative of full-time, permanent federal employees on key demographic and geographic indicators; excludes respondents planning to retire
data.notes: Two dichotomous dependent variables constructed from the item 'Are you considering leaving your organization within the next year, and if so, why?'; respondents planning to retire were omitted. Agency tenure coded as a six-point ordinal scale (1 to 6). Race/ethnicity coded as white=1, nonwhite=0. Satisfaction with benefits factor created from three items (eigenvalue=1.380, Cronbach’s alpha=0.76). Performance culture factor created from four items (eigenvalue=2.407, Cronbach’s alpha=0.87). Supervisor relationship averaged from two items. Gender was missing for nearly 140,000 respondents and was excluded from models.

method.description: The study examines how demographic, workplace satisfaction, and organizational/relational factors are associated with federal employees’ turnover intentions using 2006 FHCS data. Two binary outcomes capture intentions to leave one’s agency for another federal job or to leave the federal government for an outside position. Logistic regressions with robust standard errors clustered by agency are estimated, including interactions between age and satisfaction with benefits/advancement. Predicted probabilities and first differences are computed via Monte Carlo simulation.
steps: Obtain 2006 FHCS data and restrict to full-time, permanent federal employees.
Exclude respondents indicating plans to retire; prepare analysis sample.

Construct two binary dependent variables: (a) Leaving Agency (1 if intend to leave agency for another federal job; 0 otherwise); (b) Leaving Government (1 if intend to leave for a job outside federal government; 0 otherwise).
Code demographic variables: create age category dummies (under 30 as base; 30–39; 40–49; 50–59; 60+), agency tenure as ordinal (1–6), race/ethnicity (white=1, nonwhite=0).

Create workplace satisfaction measures: overall job satisfaction; satisfaction with pay; satisfaction with benefits factor (from retirement, health, life insurance); satisfaction with advancement opportunities.

Create organizational/relational measures: performance culture factor (merit-based promotions, rewards for quality, pay and awards depend on performance); empowerment (single item); relationship with supervisor (average of two items); relationship with coworkers (single item).
Include interaction terms: age categories × satisfaction with benefits; age categories × satisfaction with advancement.
Estimate two logistic regression models (one per outcome) with robust standard errors clustered by agency.
Compute predicted probabilities and first differences using Monte Carlo simulations (Clarify in Stata 11), holding other variables at their means.
method.models: Logistic regression with robust standard errors clustered by agency; post-estimation Monte Carlo simulation for predicted probabilities and first differences
method.outcome_variable: Turnover intention measured as two dichotomous variables: (1) Leaving Agency (intend to leave agency for another federal job); (2) Leaving Government (intend to leave federal government for an outside job).
method.independent_variables: Age categories; agency tenure; race/ethnicity (white vs nonwhite); overall job satisfaction; satisfaction with pay; satisfaction with benefits (factor); satisfaction with advancement; performance culture (factor); empowerment; relationship with supervisor; relationship with coworkers; interactions of age with satisfaction with benefits and advancement.
method.control_variables: All listed independent variables were included together to adjust for demographic, workplace satisfaction, and organizational/relational factors; interactions for age with benefits and advancement.
method.tools_software: Stata 11; Clarify program for simulation of predicted probabilities and first differences

results.summary: Overall job satisfaction is a strong, negative predictor of turnover intention for both leaving one’s agency and leaving the federal government. Age exhibits a nonlinear pattern for leaving the agency (middle age groups more likely to intend to move within government; oldest much less likely) and a consistently negative association with leaving government (older employees less likely to intend to leave federal service). Longer agency tenure reduces intentions to leave both the agency and the government. Nonwhite employees are more likely to intend to leave their agency but less likely to intend to leave the federal government compared to white employees. Satisfaction with advancement opportunities reduces turnover intention (stronger effect for leaving the agency), while satisfaction with pay has a small negative effect. Satisfaction with benefits unexpectedly increases intention to leave the agency and is unrelated to intention to leave government. A stronger performance culture slightly increases intention to leave the agency; empowerment has a small negative association with leaving government and no significant effect on leaving the agency. A better supervisor relationship reduces intention to leave the agency; coworker relationship is not significant.
